description:
I'm regular customer here. They always did a good service but today there is a server who unfriendliness. In normally server wore the black shirt but today the server didn't ware there uniform. 
I came with my friend 5 people I have a server who I never see him before.
He start with throw menu on the table. 
He didn't check any food we order.
He have very bad service mind.
He serve food likely serve for his dog.
Finally he keep the food that unfinished and give me a check that include 18% tips.

They improved their service and the test of food is really good.
author: Chinnakrit W.

description:
Was a frequent customer but will no longer order from here. Not only did they deliver my food 15 minutes late, but they forgot the beef that I had ordered. Then they refused to redeliver the correct order. Thanks for nothing. They must HATE repeat customers. Will be ordering from nearby Cocobang or another competent Korean spot. 

And avoid the corn cheese!!!
author: Ai N.

description:
Bad service, bad price
  Price did not reflect the menu and they came up with a lame excuse to fit the overpriced amount.
 Basically the waiter made up a rule to fit the price.  Meal was $11.99.  $1 for adding the noodles and $1 more for the meat.  So total should be $13.99.  waiter said the price was $14.99 since it's $1 for adding the first item and $2 more for adding a second item. Therefore, the waiter said the total should be $14.99. WTF.  This was clearly not mentioned in the menu.

Also, the waiter walked by our table many times without asking to take our order.  The waiters always kept their heads down so they would not have to look up and see customers waving to them to to help or take the order.  When wanted extra rice, I had to. Go to cashier to ask for that and the bill.  I practically served myself so I should just tip myself.
author: Sidney C.

description:
Best spot for Korean in the downtown area, hands down!

Vibes of this spot reminds me of Tonight soju bar (in Sunset Area) Super dark atmosphere, lots of people talking, chillin' & feaaaasting!

The food is pretty dang good here, galbi tang was REALLY memorable & huge. Hands down my favorite dish here! The cheese corn is suuuper bomb here as well - its huge, sweet & seems to be the closest taste of my time in Korea.

Not sure why this place isn't as popular, but I love the food here!
author: Melanie T.

description:
Zzan was the second Korean restaurant that was thrown up by Yelp, when searching for Korean food in Nob Hill, that I tried for lunch a couple of days ago. It seems to be a new restaurant that has a more clean, open and modern look. It's not too big and at the peak lunch hour seemed to be pretty full. I think you can walk in and take any open seat after which the server will come with water and the menu. The menu is typical of Korean restaurants and includes Kalbi, Galbi, Bulgogi, bibimbap, japchae, sundubu along with a bunch of snack type items to be had with drinks like Korean Fried Chicken, Cream Corn, kimchee pancake, steamed egg etc.

I decided to get the subdubu or the soft tofu soup with beef ($11.95). Five minutes after ordering I got the banchan and then the waiting started and continued for almost 20 minutes till I got my piping hot sundubu.

I got five different types of banchan each of which had a decent serving size. I didn't like the kimchi that much as I would have preferred it to be a little more fermented. The sundubu also lacked intense flavors and tasted flat. It was definitely not bad just that it lacked the zing associated with good sundubu.

Price wise it was about 20% more than 707 Sutter and 10% more than Cocobang, it's two nearest competitors. Service was slow. Getting the banchan took time, getting the sundubu took ages and finally even clearing the check seemed to happen in slow motion. I was almost relieved to be finally out when everything was done with. Taste wise also I liked the subdubu at 707 Sutter a lot better than what I got here. Zzan is another place that is A-Ok at best.
author: Ahmad J.

description:
i've been here a few times and i always forget to check in because im drunk xD i always crave korean food when im drunk.

I didnt really have a good experience this last time i went because of one of the workers was being very rude to us. she didn't acknowledge us even though she very obviously heard us... just kept walking away... and even when we got her attention, she just said "hold on" and kept walking lol we had to wait until the other server there walked by so he could help us out. i dont understand why she was being that way.

but anyways this place has some really good korean food and cheap beer! $15 for a pitcher of sapporo. I've tried their ddukboki, karaage (i always get this! very crispy and yummy), sea snail, boodae jjigae. All are very good! Not like Korea good though... but im really glad more places like this are opening up in norcal! woot!
author: Yeonhwa S.

description:
We went to San Francisco on Christmas, so there were not a lot of places open. Luckily this place was open and right by the hostel we were staying at.
We got the seasoned fried chicken and soft tofu stew. I felt like the food was decent, but the prices for what we got was too expensive. 
The chicken was delicious and the sauce was sweet and flavorful. The soft tofu stew came in four options. They had kimchi, vegetables, beef, and pork. We got the kimchi. It was good. They gave us a raw egg to put into the stew. Also, the side dishes were pretty good. 
I would say the service was slow and the place was a tad too loud with all the Korean music. However, if I was in the mood to drink and hang out, I think it would be a fun place to stop by for drinks.
author: Jane P.

description:
There were six banchan presented when I sat at the table.  Colorful and tasty, I gobbled them up!

I love spicy kimchi pancake, and I ordered the one with with seafood.

It looked delicious!  Unfortunately there wasn't much variety of seafood.  It was filled primarily with squid (I spied one shrimp in the half I ate) and was so greasy, it came out painfully the next morning.

Kinda makes me want to not try anything else. I prefer 707 Sutter.
author: Sondra H.

description: The smallest portion of food is here. Everything looks like snacks. I dont know what for they keep this price. It takes too long to get served. Not comfortable seats. Small tables.
author: Timurlan A.

description: Zzan is my favorite Korean restaurant in SF! I come here at least 5-6x a month. Aside from the food, I love their ambiance as it's good for drinking soju and I enjoy the friendly staff. There is usually a line on Friday and Saturday nights but it's worth the wait!!
author: Heera L.

description:
Stir Fried Creamy Rice Cake
Stir Fried Creamy Rice Cake
Stir Fried Creamy Rice Cake

is the best and only forever
author: Yoli X.

description: Ok, let's be honest -- Kfood scene in SF is so lacking. What a sad reality. With that said, Zzan is my go-to place for takeout dinners, especially when I feel under the weather and need a hearty dose of hot, spicy soup to comfort my body. I get their kimchi stew as I very much prefer their version of this stew among other places in SF. As for the other dishes, they are quite average (but not horrible) -- which is saying a lot since some the SF Kfood places are simply unspeakable...!
author: Lindsey O.

description:
We had kimchi fried rice, yuk-ge-jang, fried chicken, etc.
 All foods were awesome! My son who doesn't like kimchi said it's delicious. Dduk-bok-ki was the best among our orders. It's spicy but you can taste real Korean spicy food!
author: Jieun C.

description:
Came here for last minute lunch with some friends on a Friday. I actually had Korean dinner the night before at Foxsister so it was nice to have a comparison and price wise, this place was much better. The lunch for three people here was half the price as dinner for two at Foxsister.

The food here is actually very good but the waitress was not that friendly which would bring my four stars to a three. I was craving japchae and couldn't find it anywhere on the menu so I asked the waitress and she looked at me like I was an idiot when I asked her and looked angry when I asked if I could order it. Good lord. So unnecessary. 

I got the veggie bimbimbap for lunch and then the japchae which was HUGE. Good thing my cousin ended up joining and we split both dishes and we were crazy stuffed by the end of it and couldn't even finish it. The banchan was aplenty but was too scared to ask the waitress for more after she kept giving me dirty looks god knows why. 

No issues otherwise, would def come back again. I love cheap korean food and it was very tasty here.
author: Tiffany V.

description: It's cool to have a place open so late at night. I always prefer this kind of bar slash restaurant comparing to traditional bar. It's good for two person and it's also great for a group of people hang out, drinking, having conversations. One star down is for their food being over-flavored (too salty). Another star down is for shortage of waiters. Only two to three waiters are handling all tables. I still like this places because they offer a variety of choices and they are very authentic. Open late is a big plus, since this should those kind of place you go after late night concert.
author: Yanzhong L.

description: I visited Zzan with with my girlfriend and close friend from high school, and we had a terrific experience. Prior to our visit, my friend informed me that Zzan stayed true to authentic Korean food, which would be unlike other Korean places I'd visited in the past. In hindsight, I completely agree! For context, Zzan is tucked away on a side street with minimal street parking, so it can be a little tough to get there. That being said, the interior is dimly lit with LEDs and has tables scattered on both sides. We were seated after roughly 30 minutes, which appears to be the norm considering the ample customer demand. Our waitress was considerate, through a little hard to hear in the hustle-and-bustle of the restaurant. We started off by ordering vegetable tempura and fried calamari, which were quickly brought out. The tempura was light and flaky, while the calamari was large and tender. We followed-up with an order of spicy fried chicken that was both crisp and flavorful. The bill was a little higher than other places I'd been to in the past, but the food quality more than made up for it. Overall, I highly recommend visiting Zzan if you're in the area and craving authentic Korean food.
author: Murali V.

description: I dunno who the low star haters are. I lived in or within delivery distance of Los Angeles Koreatown for years and I am willing to testify on behalf of Zzan - for bone broth style soups, this place meets the absolute gold standard - perfectly spicy and not too oily, nourishing AF. Also, their delivery packaging is top notch, and they deliver on time.
author: Aditya A.

description:
First time here with my hubby on a Sunday .
Wasn't busy , so was lucky to get a good 
spot . Food was great . Ordered a bibimbap
w/ c was a lot & my hubby got a beef stew 
noodle soup ! We enjoyed it a lot . Made us 
both so full . We had to walk around to lighten
our stomachs.
author: Gloria L.

description:
The following review is based on my last visit to San Fran in April of this year:  

It was a tiny little place, mostly younger patrons with younger "vibe" BUT food was amazing. My older parents, in their mid 70s, loved everything on their menu. The best part was friendly staffs -- they were very attentive to my parents. The worst part was my parents didn't want to go any other restaurant.
author: Jandi K.

description: The kimchi fried rice (w/ spam), creamy teokbokki(10/10), boneless chicken, and cheese corn were soooooo good! It was our first time coming here and there weren't many people at that time. The atmosphere was really nice, darker lighting with light korean music at the background. The banchan portion was really small but we don't really finish it so that's alright lol. Customer service was pretty good. It was really hot that day so I just wish that they'd give out (cold) water. Overall experience was great and I want to come back next time and order the really yummy foods!
author: Sofia B.

description:
There's an unspoken triangle in Lower Nob Hill where the hipster Asians traverse usually in packs. It's not quite the Bermuda Triangle because these youngsters don't unfortunately disappear into the abyss but rather multiple exponentially usually by text until you find yourself waiting endlessly out on the street for your number at Cocobang. You pick up '58' and the young Asian host just said '7'. Let's just call it the Korean Triangle - the popular Cocobang on the right, 707 Sutter on the top, and to the left, the newest and youngest of the bunch, Zzan. You can tell this is where all the hyperactive whippersnappers go because all three are open until 2AM, Cocobang until 4AM.

I was intending to go to Cocobang but saw the crowd outside on their smartphones and scurried away. This is actually a more spacious spot than Cocobang and also a lot darker. It was easy to get a table right away here, too easy as a matter of fact, which initially concerned me. I was seated at a large, conspicuous table next to two post-adolescent Asian girls spewing profanity to each other. They were clearly the best of friends. I was perusing the multi-page menu, and as is the usual protocol, I was handed the Banchan plates moments after I told them what I wanted. Just five of them, the usual suspects including kimchi and bean sprouts and all good munchies, along with the dipping sauces for what I ordered (photo: http://bit.ly/2mddh8o).

My first dish was the $5.95 Potato Croquettes which looked perfectly round and content sitting on a sparse gathering of shredded cabbage (photo: http://bit.ly/2mwZIDs). It came with some kind of chili sauce with a mayo-like center. It was decently crispy, nothing extraordinary when it came to flavor. My main dish was the $15.95 Jok Bal, always an ambitious undertaking since it's a dish meant for a small Korean village. It's pig trotters braised in soy sauce and garlic and sliced up on a big platter (photo: http://bit.ly/2lNK082). This one was again decent, a bit dry, and surprisingly without lettuce wraps since I assume they were not saucy enough to warrant them. Oh my, here comes an army of skinny Asian youth. Perhaps they can take photos and graze on the leftovers.

FOOD - 3 stars...moderately moderate Korean food for young Asians, old ones like me need not apply
AMBIANCE - 2.5 stars...dark, clubby with tables too close together
SERVICE - 2.5 stars...intermittent
TOTAL - 3 stars...they give you a lot of piggy and taters for sure
author: Ed U.

description: Best Korean BBQ in the area, my favorite comfort food after a long day of work or perhaps having had too much to drink! Rice cake skewers, corn cheese and anything pork:) you can't go wrong no matter what you get though.
author: Morgan W.

description:
Great that it's open for late night delivery, perhaps not the best Korean delivery food I've ever had.  Ordered via UberEats, so this review is solely based on food.

- Fried Chicken with Soy Garlic Sauce ($14.95 + $1 for sauce) - a pretty decent serving of 8 pieces, so good for sharing between two people plus one more dish or so.  Slightly on the expensive side vs. other Korean fried chicken (KFC) places I know.  While the sauce was thick and delicious, and the chicken meat delicious, the skin was a disappointment.  I've done take-outs with KFC before and was satisfied, but this time the skin was not crispy at all, almost on the verge of being flabby.  A shame, considering how much we liked the sauce and such.  

- Japchae / pan fried clear noodle ($10.95) - good soy flavor, though a bit on the oily side for my taste.  Also would have preferred if there were more veggies and meat in it; seemed like they were being stingy on those.  

All in all, while I appreciate them being open late in case I get late-night Korean food cravings, didn't quite satisfy my cravings.  Think I would prefer to order / go elsewhere for my KFC or japchae, but would consider this spot if I need a quick fix late at night and I'm lazy in my apartment.
author: Audrey H.

description: Came on Sunday night at 7pm. Only two tables were taken. We three got seated quickly and ordered cheese corn, bibibam, tofu soup and seafood ramen. The side dishes were just okay compared to other korean restaurant, but the food we ordered was super tasty. I especially liked the cheese corn and bibibam. To be honest, I really want to give 5 stars, but the service was just mediocre. Please note that the tip was already added to the check, and it was 18% of the whole bill. The server who gave us the check didn't even remind us. And we have to ask for sure. Down for this. As the food indeed stood out, we were fine with the bill.
author: Shiyun L.

description:
This hit the spot after drinking. Had the cheesy corn, bulgogi, and dubboki (spicy rice cakes).

I'd rec getting cheesy corn and spicy rice cakes but was not a fan of the bulgogi. The meat tasted right but it was chopped up which I didn't like.

Price wise it's about right. Service was pretty slow (too many tables, not enough servers).
author: Mimi T.

description: Pretty good/decent. Nothing serious to complain about. Staff if cool, chill vibe. Food could be a bit more flavorful though.
author: Cecile ..

description: Skip: the chicken karraage. More batter than meat.
author: Kristen S.

description:
I LOVE coming here, they're open later than normal San Francisco restaurants, and also open on most holidays like Christmas, NYE, etc. Their selection is great, and everything is tasty. Definitely a shorter line than Cocobang, and I think the food is on par. 

Our go to order is beef short rib soup and an order of their fried chicken with soy garlic sauce on the side. The beef short rib soup is clear, but the broth so rich and flavorful. The beef is soft and tender, with some tasty bits of daikon radish and egg, and clear noodle. It offsets the crunchy, tasty fried chicken, too. The portion is quite large, perfect for two people. 

I'm a huge fan of their kimchi pancake and combination pancake, although the seafood pancake doesn't have alot of seafood at all (a few pieces of octopus legs and 2 shrimp). Their bibimbap is quite good, not the best.
author: Ke C.

description:
the kinda korean late night spot where you'll actually find Koreans eating and drinking. The anju (Korean cuisine to accompany alcohol) options are delicious. Prices are a tad high but not unreasonably so, and the good food and fun ambiance makes it worth it. My friends and I shared the honghap tang (mussel soup) and nakji bokkeum (stir-fried octopus w noodles--as much as I feel guilty for eating such an intelligent creature, it's so delicious and worth it) to accompany our many bottles of Chamisul Fresh soju and Hite beers. If you don't like soju shots, try Chamisul Fresh mixed with Korean beer (so-maek, short for soju-maekju, or soju-beer). Or try a flavored soju--they're all deliciously light and not sugary.  

PS. Cocobang is overrated and more and more inauthentic these days. Try Zzan instead.
author: Christine K.

description:
there are many korean restaurants which close late night in downtown. this one is one of my favorite. selections are good, and taste of foods are also above average. if you want some korean food or any food for late night in down town, you should try this place. they also have beers on tap and korean soju. love to drink at late night here. so  here are my rates.
food 4/5
service 5/5
interior 2/5
location 5/5
hour 5/5
price 5/5

it is 4.5/5
author: Chris L.

description:
Ok so this is probably some of the worst Korean food I've had. The clear noodle (japchae) isn't quite flavorless, but it is not good...the kimchi fried rice is also not good...
I feel like they're both missing key ingredients....
I'm honestly sad that I spent the money on this... and I was super excited for Korean food today...
author: Alexandra R.

description: Great service and food! Would definitely recommend to others. Prices are reasonable and atmosphere is welcoming.
author: Yani D.

description: Incredibly lackluster. Ordered from eat24 and will never order from again. While the delivery was fast and seamless, the food was terrible. I ordered the galbi, the jjampong, and fried chicken in soy garlic sauce. The galbi was the only thing that was semi-good. Not terrible, not the best I've had. I felt this tasted like the frozen ones you can buy and make yourself from Trader Joe's. The fried chicken was not anything close to Korean Fried Chicken. I get it, I ordered it for delivery, but I've ordered fried chicken before that took a longer time to be delivered and was still crispy. This wasn't crispy at all. It was more like roasted chicken wings tossed in a sweet/salty sauce. The jjampong was terrible; the broth had no absolutely no flavor. All in all, I spent about $50+. Terrible waste of money.
author: Kelsey T.

description:
Discovered this place on Yelp when I was looking for food with high protein after my workout at 24 hour fitness down the block. Zzan was pretty new back then and looking at those tofu and egg pictures, decided to give this place a try!

* * * EXPERIENCE * * *
Pros:
- Friendly and very attentive staff
- Varieties on menu
- Good atmosphere for hipsters gathering

Cons: Can't think of any!

* * * FOOD * * *
Seafood Tofu Soup: A-.
Tofu was very soft. Lots of seafood inside, the shrimps used were pretty fresh. Tasty soup!

Steamed Egg: A-.
Love their steamed egg! The bowl was pretty big, and saltiness was just about right. The puffiness of egg was to the point.

One of my favorite Korean food places in SF!
author: Simon C.

description:
Love their ...
* Beef Soft Tofu Soup with Kimchi
* Corn with Cheese
author: Mindy - Oishii Moments S.

description:
I throw my bd party here. Everything was so lovely
Their food r fantastic and waitress always tried to help us
I made the right decision to choose this place
Even it was too small but waitress, she tried to help us all the time
Thank u guys u made my day
author: Yokyok N.

description:
Thx yelp.. K-pop meets korean food.

Cool korean pop, hip hop videos playing on the wall...

Fun place, very reasonable prices. Mix of korean and non korean 20/30 yr olds...sort of trendy crowd.

Friendly service,  nice cold beer/shoju. Plenty of food.

Representing Hawaii we had the "army" soup..
Mix of all that is found in a mamasans kitchen sink..
-veggies (nicely cut and arranged and a great assortment enoki, won bok, carrots, green onion etc)
-hot dog
-spam
-ramen
-beef
And the list goes on and on.  Lovely broth with a
Slight kick of heat...Great korean sides. Also had the rice cake yakitori app.. (Like fried mochi with sweet/hot sauce) yum.

Id come back.. Great job guys!  Venture beyond "trendy" new american gastro pub stuff and give this place a shot..
author: Jodi M.

description: Came here with my sister's and it was packed! The wait for our tables came by quite fast. Food was good and it's a good environment to come w/ friends or family for a drink or more! I'd suggest if you have a big crowd come early or see if they are willing to reserve.
author: Kristina X.

description:
The No1DP and I only had a couple of hours left in SF and given SFO's limited lunch options in the international terminal I wanted to have my last meal within the confines of the city. A quick Yelp search revealed this spot within a 5 minute walk of the hotel.

Though the full menu was available we opted for the lunch menu. We got the same item - beef spicy soft tofu soup ($10.95). Side soup was an egg miso, which was a bit watery with bits of egg white. They gave us four small banchans to munch on in addition to the soup and egg. The No1DP didn't crack an egg onto his soup.

Soup was okay. For a soft tofu soup there was LOTS of tofu. I actually could eat the soup without rice as there was already lots of carb. Very underwhelmed by the amount of beef. Spice level was decent though the No1DP was surprised on how spicy it was. 

This serving, though average by my regular lunch standards certainly beats any lunch option I can find at SFO and certainly cheaper. For a quick lunch it certainly did its job of satisfying my appetite.
author: Isabella B.

description: Probably my favorite Korean joint now.  Food was sooo fresh  and fairly priced considering it's downtown.
author: Mg M.

description:
Zzan is a solid option when its one of those "Oh crap it's Wednesday, there is no way I am cooking and I want something tasty but am not getting in an Uber" moments. 

NOTE: This review is for take-out, not dine in. 

We got the bibimbap and they were generous with the portion size and great with the veggies but the beef was a bit sauce-heavy/ had some binder and over-sweetness going on. Full disclosure, "overly sweet" is one of my most common issues with food, so this may be my personal taste. The presentation was impressive for to-go (although it was not ready at pickup time, they finalized the last components real quick-like!) 

The yam noodles were delicious as usual, albeit with a heavy slick of oil, but let's be honest- nobody orders them as health food!
author: Lisa M.

description: Food is really good here and the service is great. It's a loud and lively atmosphere with good Korean dishes. I only go here for this one waitress though. She already rejected me like twice, but Idc.
author: TJ P.

description:
Zzan is one of my boyfriend's favorite location and he absolutely loves this place. We come here pretty often, and there is usually no wait. They have flavored but not yogurt based soju. So you can get bottles of soju with flavor like peach, pineapple etc, but it's clear. I've brought my co workers and friends to this location and they've all loved it. When I come here, I usually get the chicken wings, theyre amazing! It's a must try. We end up getting at least one bottle of clear flavored soju, along with dubboki, with ramen added. It's amazing!! They have pretty quick service, the staff is friendly, and I definitely am a repeat customer to this location. I really recommend this location to anyone that has not tried it. Cocobang is nearby and that is a primary choice for most, but if Cocobang is busy, which it is usually, then come here, and try this!!

Price and value 5/5
Taste 4/5
Service 4/5
author: Amy Y.

description:
With a futuristic "Blade Runner"-esque atmosphere, Zzan is an interesting restaurant that probably resembles a Korean pub with its constant stream of largely-projected K-pop MVs on the wall. Perhaps that was why my parent were taken aback initially at this decor that was clearly targeted to youngsters - blame me for not researching too thoroughly. Thankfully, because of my ignorance and stubbornness to stay, I discovered this delicious Korean restaurant in the Union Square area!

The menu is brief but straightforward: you want bibimap, KFC, or stir-fry? Then you'll easily find it on here! Despite its futuristic decor, you can find your favorite classic Korean dishes. 

Although the price was a bit higher than I would like - about $12 per entree on average, I was surprised by the portions: the bibimap was generously sized and the KFC order came with so many large pieces! The tofu soup was disappointingly small but I was too happy with the rest of the meal to care. As impressive as the portions, the bibimap was particularly delicious and the taste even differed between a seafood bibimap and a pork bibimap! I am usually indifferent about Korean cuisine because of my frequent disappointments with other places, but few restaurants like Zzan always reminded me to give this cuisine another chance.

While the decor was probably not geared toward family dining, it's not necessarily a hindrance. With the portion considered, the price was rather reasonable, but the deliciousness of the food certainly is worth it! If you are looking for a delicious Korean meal around Union Square, Zzan is it.

---
tl;dr version:
1) Futuristic K-pop themed restaurant
2) Reasonably priced, generously portioned, delicious food!
author: Jay Y.

description: Came on a Tuesday night around 7:00? It was crazy busy, put our name and phone down on a waiting list. Decide to go next door to have a drink & to wait for our turn.. 8 o'clock rolls around and still no call we decide to walk back. I guess they forgot to call us because almost all the tables have different people... we got dat immediately because of good timing there was literally one table open and another waiting line beginning. The waitress that took my name down saw us and sat us. We ordered the Kalbi, pork belly, tofu stew, pan fried dumplings, and spicy rice cakes.. everything was yummy. The rice cakes were really spicy but good. We also ordered peach soju which was nice. Waitresses were busy (there were only 2) but got us everything we needed!
author: Andrea F.

description: Pretty tiny place for how much people want to eat here. should relocate to a bigger area. Food was real good. Service was great. Great place to be loud haha Kpop playing through a projector onto a wall. Entertaining I suppose. Yo get the corn with cheese! Also get the rice cake! I love Korean food and this place nailed it! Soju bottles were like $10-$13 each. They got pitchers of soju! A must!  My friends and i really enjoyed the plate of skewers. Everyone around us seemed to have gotten this hot steaming bowl of noodles, regrets, should have gotten that too haha.
author: Connie C.

description:
Why is this so loud?!? Mind you there was about 4 separate parties here.

Came here for a late dinner with the bad because cocobang was too crowded.

Place is small.

We got the cheese corn- looked way better in pictures, and it tasted like it was cooked hours ago and put back in the microwave when we ordered it.
Spicy chicken karage- good amount of spice and good crunchy texture
Fried rice omelet with spam- I wish they used more egg for the actual omelet but overall I enjoyed this 

We sat towards the back and it was so hard to get our servers attention. We noticed she was at the table behind us DRINKING with probably some regulars or people that work there?
This really annoyed us. She would quickly walk past us it was hard to get her attention.
Don't see myself coming back as none of the food was to die for.
author: Brittany C.

description: I came in here with a group of friends looking grab some food and drinks. Happily satisfied with the service as they brought out our orders of soju and Cass beer. We ordered quite a bit of food: kimchi fried rice, spicy rice cakes, japchae, combination skewers, cheese corn, and more. It was an amazing time especially with the alcohol we ordered. Food was on point and nothing to complain about. If you're around SF, definitely a place to hit up
author: Kevin C.

description:
This place has a similar ambiance to 707 Sutter; both have dimmed lighting, huge projector playing K-POP music videos and similar menus. 
However, Zzan is a lot smaller and has better side dishes. I was surprised that they didn't give us kimchi in our banchan so we asked for it and they have it to us. 

I ordered the Seafood Tofu Soup and I thought it lacked in flavor meanwhile, my bf's Tofu Soup w/ Pork had little to no flavor..
Also ordered the spicy rice cakes and we both thought the sauce was too sweet compared to other places.
author: Leilani Y.

description: Really mediocre and flavorless food. Mediocre service. They don't take Amex. Seriously this makes it sound like a Korean joint at a Des Moines shopping center circa 1987. Who goes here?
author: Tad D.

description:
Another entry into the list of late night Korean spots in downtown.  On the smaller side, but a little bigger than Cocobang, Zzan was able to accommodate our large group as a walk in.  Granted it was a holiday sunday and not much was going on downtown.  Service is quick and friendly.

We had a bunch of soju and beer which is pretty much the same at all the Korean bars, but Zzan has a buy 6 soju bottles for $50.  Which was decent.   

The food hit on few parts.  The steam pork feet cuts was pretty good and good sized portion.  The chicken gizzards were amazing.  Good drinking food.  The fried chicken was on the spicy side, but one of the better ones I've had in the city.  

The miss was on the kimchi fried rice, I thought it was a bit bland.  We ordered the brisket soup too, but I don't remember it as a stand out, but it wasn't bad, I just don't remember...

Overall a decent spot to go to if the 707 is busy or not open.
author: Veasna H.

description:
Finally a good Korean restaurant in San Francisco. 

Great Kimchee with plenty of flavor and just the right amount of heat.

The Good:

Bulgogi BBQ - Excellent

Corn with cheese - Wasn't expecting too much but it was great

Stone Bowl Bibim Bap - Excellent

Spicy Clear Noodle - Excellent

Chicken Skewers - Succulent tasty thigh meet - excellent

Grilled Asparagus and Bacon - Excellent


The No So Good:

Steamed Korean Sausage - Did not like this. Not enough flavor in the meat, too much fat, which all doesn't turn out so well when steamed.

This is my new favorite Korean restaurant in the downtown San Francisco area.
author: David T.

description:
Another just A-OK Kpopish restaurant to go with Cocobang and 707 Sutter. They have a decent lunch menu with different options like lunch boxes with bulgoki, chicken, spicy pork and short ribs. 

I had the army stew for $11.95 and it was small for the price. It had instant ramen noodles, spam, hot dog and kimchi. The broth was just ok not spicy at all. The side dishes were only 5, kimchi, fishcake, bean sprouts, japchae and carrotts marinaded in soy sauce/vinegar. They were all on the bland side. 

The food took a long time to come out and the male server acknowedged it and apologized. It wasn't even busy at 12:30 pm with 3 other tables that recieved most of their food already. If the food takes 30 minutes to come out I expect it to be good but it was just ok. 

He did give 10% off the bill which was a nice gesture. Service was not the greatest, he brought the banchan out to a lady that arrived after us a lot quicker than he did for us and checked up on other tables but failed to come to our table. Perhaps, he felt bad it took so long.

3.5 stars at best but if in area, rather go to 707 or Coco.
author: James H.

description: The bulgogi and bibimbap were delicious! The service was friendly and efficient. Prices reasonable. We enjoyed eating amongst so many young, happy Koreans!
author: Gina D.

description:
:: The Menusic Of Erich Zzan ::

Yet when I ate at that highest of all table windows, ate while the customers sputtered and the insane kpop howled with the night-wind, I saw no sf spread below, and no homeless gleaming from remembered streets, but only the blackness of food illimitable; unimagined food alive with projection and music, and having semblance to every k-resto on these blocks.

Former fashion model turned dad(!) leaves cocobang & opens his first solo venture. Ambitiously big menu in the process of thinning & improving; you've seen these dishes before.

(^_^) Pig Feet / Jokbal $15.95 (http://bit.ly/1LvxXRZ)
Orson from US Acres.

(^_^) Blood Intestine / Sundae $10.95 (http://bit.ly/1L5283L)
Use your other food's dip sauces.

(^_^) Meme Typeface / Impact (http://bit.ly/1L528kd)
You had me at Impact typed menu.

(-_^) Karaage Spicy "Source" $10.95 (http://bit.ly/1iLy3tK)
Sweet & sour chicken, minus sour.

And as I sat there eating in hanger, the wind blew out both the customers in that ancient peaked resto, leaving me in savage and penetrable dishes with chaos and pandemonium before me, and the daemon madness of that night-baying kpop behind me.

#fulldisclosure 4th star bc our runway days together #goodtimes #nobromo #yesstylemo
author: Dan B.

description:
Service is awful!!!! Unfriendly server. Would never go there again. 

We were the only two waiting and keep waving to be seated. But they are all busy working and I understand, it's okay. We stand there for like 5 minutes. Then comes a couple and the server come immediately and send them to a table. 

I'm kind of angry and ask why, he asked 【"why are you angry and shout? Do you want to eat or not? Can't you just wait one more second?" 】In a very impolite and unfriendly way. 

Then we waited another 5 more minutes, with no sign of being taken to a seat. So we leave. Very disappointed. 

Please, I just wanted to be treated fairly. Of course I come here to eat. Is this your way of treating the consumer? Shame on you!
author: Myra Z.

description:
Don't go here!! This place is the worst! I'm usually not too hard on restaurants but we have tried this place a few times because we like to help local businesses and it's one of the only Korean options by our place. The staff is the rudest I have ever experienced, and the food is mediocre. 

In addition, a few of the times we tried to give them business through eat24, we Ordered online and they cancelled our order saying their kitchen was "broken". My husband was already at the restaurant to pick up the food, and their kitchen was definitely NOT broken as they had customers eating. Shame on you zzann! 

I would rate this place a zero if I could.
author: Jessica J.

description: Love the fried chicken and corn cheese over here!!!!!! Amazing !!
author: Judy Z.

description: Their servers are friendly and attentive and their chicken wings are bomb! Other must trys: stone bowl bibimbap, soy garlic wings, beef rib soup, and everything else :)
author: Sui N.

description: Don't go to this restaurant unless you want to get food poisoned like me! Dirty tableware, smelly water and stale food!
author: Chris W.

description:
I was reluctant on coming here because I read previous reviews on how rude the staff was here ... but luckily, that did not happen to me (and fingers crossed it never will) 

So I came here for dinner one night, and to my delight, it wasn't busy with customers-- not sure if that's a reoccurring theme or not, considering it's tucked away on Post St. 

The staff was attentive, and I appreciated how they frequently checked in on my boyfriend and I. The food came very quickly, and it was all so tasty! I recommend all of it:

- pan fried dumpling 
- clear noodle 
- beef short BBQ 

I especially like the song selection; they played a lot of hip-hop and rap music. The way the lighting is set up makes your photos look like you're in a hot club or something, I love it! The pricing is pretty decent, too, for Korean food.
author: Rachel M.

description: Food is delicious! Perfect for drunchies, but also for a casual meal. I wouldn't say the food is traditionally Korean, but it is tasty. I personally like Zzan more than Coco Bang. I think Zzan's food is more flavorful. Music is loud Kpop, perfect place to drink and pregame before going out, or to postgame since they are open late. Definitely not quiet or classy, but they have great food!
author: Michelle H.

description:
TL;DR - Best korean food in union square when you're pumped full of alcohol.

My favorite watering hole is a mere two blocks from Zzan and (unfortunately) I find myself here more often than I would like...

Taking off stars for:
1. Lack of cleanliness. Its like a dive bar vibe... except I'm eating food.
2. Awkward kpop music videos. Stop showing me stick thin girls while I gorge myself on corn cheese, galbi and all the carbs. 

Regardless, the food is pretty solid Korean bar-ish food. You've got the corn cheese, budaejiggae, kimchi fried rice. Yum.

The service we get is 50/50. Sometimes we are ignored, sometimes we get stellar service. In the end, it doesn't matter because all my hypothalamus wants is for this greasy, salty food to get in my tummy and to food coma immediately after.
author: Crystal Z.

description: I spent Memorial Day weekend in the Bay Area and had my first meal at Zzan. I flew into SF on a late weekday night and was craving something warm and soupy, and my friend took me here for some homey Korean food. The inside of the restaurant was super loud with a bunch of diners still eating away at 11PM and K-pop booming in the background. We were seated immediately. I ordered the Soondubu w/ beef because it fulfilled the "warm" and "soup" criteria. It took awhile for the dish to come out, but I was really impressed by the flavors. In fact, I'm pretty sure it was the best Soondubu I've ever had. I burned most my tongue because I gulped it down so quickly. Would definitely recommend this joint for yummy Korean food!
author: Diane M.

description:
Came here with friends on a Saturday night. It wasn't as busy as I expected and we were able to be seated immediately. We ordered 3 dishes to share: soft tofu soup, combination (kimchi and seafood) pancake and soy chicken. 

The foot itself was kind of disappointing. The soft tofu soup had huge chunks of tofu that didn't seem like they were cut up at all. It was suppose to be seafood soup but there was barely any seafood. The kimchi pancake was on the bland side, but with the sauce it was pretty tasty. As for the chicken, it was the biggest disappointing out of our 3 dishes. The skin was seasoned but the meat itself was very bland and hard to chew.

I'd probably come back for drunchies but probably not for an actual dinner.
author: Cassie Z.

description:
I came here for lunch one weekend with my girlfriends. We were the only table for quite awhile. 

Atmosphere was nice, Korean music was playing constantly, place was clean, waitstaff was friendly and attentive. 

Food was mostly great! Good banchan and soondubu & soybean paste stew. Ordered the seafood pajeon as an appetizer- was completely uncooked in the entire middle so that was really disappointing especially since we were the only table there. 

Will wait awhile and try them again later once they've been open longer.
author: Mandi W.

description: Came here on a Saturday night and it was busy! Buuuut the servers were very polite even though they said it would be an hour wait, we waited around 30-45 minutes for a table. They were quick to take our order. We ordered the spicy rice cakes, Kim Chee fried rice, jjapaghetti and corn and cheese. Every dish was delicious. I always order spicy rice cakes at every Korean spot I go, and these were just the right amount of chewy and spice. They had music videos playing in the background and toned down lighting. If you want a night out with your significant other or a small group of 4-5, this place is perfect. They had a variety of beers and flavored soju. Overall, I really enjoyed the food. Will definitely be coming back.
author: Sammie A.

description:
I don't have much experience with Korean food but this place was pretty good. Service was great and quick and the food came out pretty quickly. We ordered the Soft Tofu soup (vegetarian) and the Spicy Chewy Noodle (Vegetarian). They can make several of their dishes vegetarian which is great! However, they have us a couple small appetizers like seaweed and kimchi and also included fish cakes which was a little odd. I didn't know if these were standard sides or were meant to go with one of the dishes. 

While the soup was just ok, I really enjoyed the sticky noodle and the spicy sauce it came with.
author: Rachel N.

description:
It was awful, the food was food's quality was pretty good but now these days just getting worst! 
They put less ramen there and charges the same price!
author: Iris S.

description:
Honestly, the food is bad. Either salty or no taste at all.

Also, I order their drink special, a liter HITE beer plus soju for $19.95. Several order of it actually. But on the bill they charged separately, and when I inquired, they said they cant change it because the manager wasnt there. wtf? OK I will pay for it and give you that much less in tips.
author: Tj K.

description:
The creamy rice cake was delicious - however, not super vegetarian friendly.  Some of their food WILL have meat even though it's not mentioned at ALL in the description of the food item.  I had to send mine back because they randomly added bacon in it without ever mentioning that it has it.  Their broths are beef-based so you need to specifically ask for a veggie broth if you are a vegetarian.

The ambiance is fun, but it's really loud in there.  There's fun k-pop playing on a projector that could use a decrease of quite a few decibels.
author: Guy D.

description: Second time I've ordered for delivery that the order took 90 minutes and that the (small) soup container was 2/3 full. Won't be ordering again.
author: Molly Z.

description: I didn't want to complain the restaurant, but the delivery food looked like a disaster. Maybe I will choose to eat at restaurant next time. The delivery service is disappointed.
author: Xiuling X.

description:
Reading yelpers claiming this is the best Korean food in this area, we decided to stop since we were in this area. Dead smack during lunch time where there were only 2 tables are filled should be a red flag. Ah, you never know unless you tried it. That's what we did, so we ordered:

* Japchae - I've made this at home numerous times and it's my first time eating it from a Korean restaurant. Is this supposed to be that sweet? I can't taste a thing from this dish except sweetness. Seriously, sugar overload. 

* Bulgogi BBQ - meh. Beef was bland, and fully cooked served on a cast iron platter (and not even sizzling!). Especially the beef was thinly shredded, it came out liked a tattered mess, just the presentation itself was not appealing.

* Spicy tofu soup with ramen - Ramen is literally the instant noodles they stuck in the soup. Though this is spicy tofu soup, but wasn't too spicy which was appreciated. Lots of tofu and not much else.

* Chicken bibimap - ordered with the stone bowl, again, no big deal. I've had better. Chicken was meh. Just get the stone bowl for the crunchy rice at the bottom. Add that to the spicy tofu soup was a great way to have the rice.

* Banchans - not much variety either.

At the end of our meal, we found ourselves the only ones in the restaurant. The chef and the only waiter stepped outside taking smoke break - another red flag. Sorry, way to many great Korean restaurants in the city, chances of us coming back is very slim.
author: Em T.

description:
Delicious food and very friendly service! Highly recommend to check it out. 

I came here via Allset app (order your lunch in advance) and when we came everything were all set and waited for us. Food is very tasty, portions are huge and the stuff is very attentive. Great place for your lunch break!
author: Anna I.

description: I was surprised to see this place didn't have more positive reviews as the food and service were excellent. I highly recommend it. We were wondering around trying to find somewhere decent without a crazy wait and after striking out several times wandered in and got a table immediately. Focus in on the bibimbop, salad with beef while your chicken wings cool down and then of course the k-pop videos that have you scratching your head wondering if those girls are 13 or 30.
author: Chris H.

description: We shared a seafood stew and the grilled pork belly. Both were fantastic. Service was friendly and quick. Ask for some extra kimchee and pair your meal with some soju and you've hit a home run.
author: Roger B.

description:
Very meh. Ordered takeout from here on a night I was craving Korean hard and couldn't make it out and it barely checked the box.

The seafood pancake was soggy and falling apart and the bibimbap chicken was mostly flavorless. Luckily it came with bibimbap sauce so I drowned the dish in it and that seemed to do the trick.
author: Jennifer L.

description:
I love every food there but... especially for foreigners, be careful! There is a server who is really unkind, sometimes rude ^^ Other servers are very fine, but the impolite server doesn't seem to wanna sell something or smile ^^ If my brain works well, I remember the server's name is Jay. Whenever I go there with foreign friends and there he is, I get ashamed of introducing that Korean restaurant ^^ Does the owner like it? Wow incredible ^^
                        ^^...   ?        ,        ,    ,               ...                  ?                      ^^     ,      ,                ?     ?  ?     ?               ,      ,     ...   ^^
author: Winning C.

description:
I found zzan on yelp while I was starving around the downtown area and craving asian food. I think the asian food selection around this area is limited and zzan's about a 10-15 min walk away from market street. I liked the food overall. We ordered the seafood pancake, short rib soup, and bibimbap. 

They play loud korean music to emulate party-like korean restaurants. I would say it's not bad for a Korean restaurant within walking distance of union square. Would come back next time I'm craving asian food and too lazy to go over to the richmond.
author: Annie Z.

description:
Pro Tip: Order the Korean chicken wings. They are amaaaaaaaazing!

After a long flight to San Francisco I came here with a friend to grab some late night grub. The interior is super casual and a bit divey but being hypnotized by K-Pop videos makes everything disappear in the background. We ordered some shochu which was very reasonable at $13 a carafe along with an array of dishes such as the Korean chicken wings, kim chee fried rice and spicy chewy noodles. Earnestly all I need after a hard day are those chicken wings and a big bowl of rice. A word to the wise, don't get all your dishes spicy because I think you need the contrast of plain and spicy or else your entire meal starts tasting like one big mess. Banchan was not the best I've ever had, but I did enjoy the radishes which were served with those amazing chicken wings.
author: Emi H.

description:
I don't know why they have such bad rating from some people. You're not going here to have authentic Korean food. It's more about the young and trendy atmosphere with decent Korean food to have with soju. I love their music selection too. Service, never had problem with. Just because they don't smile doesn't mean they are being rude to you. I've had non-korean friends visit here and they had great time there and never complained about service. 

If you want authentic Korean food, go to Han Il Kwan. 
If you want decent korean food AND rolls, go to Izakaya Ninja. 
If you want Korean style friend chicken, go to Cocobang. 
If you want decent korean food with fun soju drinking time with friends, definitely go here, ZZAN.
author: Sm Y.

description:
Ok I'm writing this review based on reading some negative things. That didnt speak to my experience at all. Though they seemed overwhelmed a bit, the staff was friendly and accommodating and apologetic and checked in multiple times.

I ordered assorted seafood with noodle (togo) and whole octopus stirfry (stay). Both were delicious, flavorful and portion size matched the price. Ban chon was very good. Rice and noodles were fresh. 

You have a choice of cocobang and 707 in the immediate area and i would easily choose Zzan. Cocobang was good but not memorable (save for the long wait) and my one experience at 707 was unfriendly, overpriced and bulgogi was near-beef jerky dry. Seriously, it felt like the leftover bulgogi from the grill. I will say their seafood pancake was good.

I don't go to restaurants twice unless I had an exceptional experience. I've been to Zzan twice in two days and will likely order again in the next couple days.
author: stuart l.

description:
Really excited to see a new Korean spot pop up in the Lower Nob Hill Area!

The 2 other places I usually go to are Jin Mi or 707 Sutter. Jin Mi can be hard to get to since it's in a pretty rough neck of the TL, and 707 can get really busy.

Zzan provides the trendy fun atmosphere of 707, and they have the food to back them up.

Be greeted by dark walls which highlight the K-pop music videos playing on the screen. Energetic servers quickly come by to take your order and poor beer.

So far I've tried their Jap Chae, tofu soup, and Hot Stone Bibimbap.
When I told them I was vegetarian, they even made sure to swap out the side dishes to make sure they were all veggie-friendly. A small touch I really appreciated.

Everything is cooked well, served hot, and really spicy-just the way I like it.
It is open super late as well, 2am on most nights. 

The times I've been here, every table is filled, but the wait isn't too bad.
This is now one of my favorite new spots in town!
author: Lanie L.

description: The chicken was great. I got there at 530pm and it was just about full. If you're going during dinner rush expect a bit of a wait.
author: Joseph M.

description:
You're go to late night Korean mini bar!

Basic Korean dishes, condiments aren't a lot but it will do.

Came here mainly just for the soju but the cheese corn and pigs feet are worth a try! Will be back on my late nights in the city.
author: Connie H.

description: Stopped in for a quick lunch. The Bibimbop box with kimchee and veggies was just fantastic. Topped it off with an ice cold Sapporo. Quick and friendly service. Very small but cozy.
author: Katie W.

description:
Random Saturday night shenanigans and we ended up here because we wanted dduk bbok ki and kkampunggi (spicy rice cakes and korean fried wings). 

Somehow between 3 girls we had 2 things of flavored soju, some kind of raspberry wine as well and this was well after taking shots and having drinks at 3 other places previously. 

Needless to say we were having a good time.  I love how they have korean and american music playing with their music videos projected on the wall.  

Let's talk food though: Banchan: pretty good and they kept coming out as we were munching on them.  They also have REAL kkamppungi (korean chicken wings) rather than the cut up pieces of chicken they have at other places.  The amount of wings was ridiculous! They were perfectly seasoned and crunchy, came out piping hot!  We also got ddukbokki which was good too- little different with a little more sweetness than usual which was perfecto.  

Drinks: Strawberry soju was bomb.  Yogurt soju was to me- okay.  They tend to blend their flavored sojus which is different than what I'm used to in ktown in LA, but I'm not hating on it.  Makes sure that it's extra cold. ;)  It made it harder to shoot, which I guess was a good thing or else I would've been further gone quicker.  I do like the flavored soju they do here only because it's a little less sweet than usual. This is a good thing as I don't like overly sweet. 

Service: 100%  Andy oppa's the best. :)
author: Meena N.

description:
The best korean food in SF!

its one of me and my husband's favorite places to drink and eat!  and we are always so happy with the food and kind services there.

they have mostly everything from Korean meals to drinks & snacks, everything on the menu is delicious but our favorite is cheese bul dak(spicy grilled chicken) Must try!!

I also highly recommend this restaurant to anyone who wants to have a great experience by awesome proud staff!
author: Maki J.

description: The individual dishes are really good, and the staff are super friendly.  However, the bento boxes have much to be desired.  The pork katsu was too dry.  The fried pancakes were drowning in cooking oil.  The fried pot stickers weren't bad.  If they can improve the bento boxes, that'd be great.
author: Kimberly H.

description: Strong spice broth. Perfect taste for the one who like strong favor. It was the best kimchi stew(with pork belly) I ever had.
author: IT F.

description: Ordered via Yelp Eat24. Craved for seafood pancake, tofu soup, Kim Chee fried rice and boiled calamari!  Drooling just thinking about these k-food! Been doing loads of delivery and this was a yummy spot.
author: Vee V.

description: Too much attitude on the phone! I saw a picture of their beef noodle on Yelp, and bae and I were out late in SF. Wanted some late night viddles, so I pulled out my trusty Yelp app (of course) and took a look. My sweetie had his Yelp on too, and he called first. I could hear through the phone and my bf asked him what different kinds of noodles they had, and he said "Well, this is a Korean place... did you know that?" "Uh.. well I just wanted to know if you had different kinds? Like chicken or" "I think you want a Chinese place. We don't have noodles like that." Boom...and he hung up. We were both kinda like damn... ok. Maybe I'll have better luck if I call. Nope. "Hi there! (I even lifted my voice 2 octaves to sound more fresh and friendly) what kind of noodles do you have?" "Sigh" (Uh oh. He must have known I was with the last call)  "We don't have noodles". In the nastiest tone. Then hung up. Wow. Fuuuuuck you too I guess? Customer service starts on the phone. Get into it.
author: Jennifer S.

description:
Bad Korean food I have ever had.
I ordered plain fried chicken ( $1 extra for the sauce) and it was very bland no taste at all.
author: Misstar C.

description:
A much needed new spot in DTSF! Service is superb any day you go in, even on a busy Saturday evening! 

Must try their iced soju that comes in a variety of flavors--kiwi, mango, peach, guava, and strawberry. 

Love the ban chan (appetizer dishes)--Kimchee tasted fresh! 

Galbi was made to perfection--tender and juicy. 

Combination tofu soup had everything I asked for--from beef to seafood. Make sure to get the extra spicy! 

Kimchee fried rice--can never go wrong with this! Again, fresh Kimchee goes a long way.

Would definitely come back!
author: Judy L.

description:
Great food, great service, interesting atmosphere.  Love that it stays open late, highly recommended.

I think the prices are very reasonable

Only minor thing was the food was a bit too salty
author: Jorlyn W.

description: Worst Korean restaurant ever! I had an army soup yesterday and I spent the whole night vomiting. The kimchi they served has gone bad. The ingredients in the soup must have gone bad too. It was really spicy thus the bad taste was not easy to recognize. Please stop poisoning your customer!!!
author: Grace X.

description: I'm Korean and this place makes me happy- going back tonite. We had mackerel, kimchi pancake and Bi bim bop- all yummy. Soju was great too!
author: Jungah L.

description:
It's not a trip to San Francisco if I am not dancing to K-Pop and eating Korean food with my number 1 volcano goddess. It's just the way we do things.* I'm surprised to see the star rating for Zzan. I really enjoyed myself.

The space is unassuming. I like that what the restaurant didn't put into decor and fancy jibber jabber, they put into a huge-a$$ TV that played hit after hit of K-Pop. #priorities Even though I was sad that I didn't hear/see one Miss A joint while we were there, there was plenty of infectiously ridiculous music to keep me entertained and ADHD-addled. As is our tradition, my friend and I started with a carafe of soju... that turned into carafeS of soju. We can't help it. When flavors come in peach and strawberry and are so bright and colorful... and the music video are so bright and colorful... you're in too deep. You just have to keep drinking. You can't fight the moonlight.

DrAnks flowin' and dubs bumpin', it was a smart idea to get some food in the belly. Thing is, when you're tipping back the drAnks and paying more attention to the 2946 members of the latest K-Pop boy band on the large video screen, you over order. You might try to eat everything on the table but you will fail. At least it'll taste good as you admit defeat. Far and away, you have the get the chicken wings (obviously from mutant chickens, given the enormous size of the wings. I'm not complaining). We ordered the soy garlic wings and let me tell you this: in the 7 years we have been friends, we've never had an argument. In trying to determine who was going to eat the last wing, we almost came to blows. I decided to be a Southern gentleman and let her have it.** I don't think I would have given up so easily if it weren't for the kimchi fried rice I was killing. Oh, and what was that? Spicy noodles to slurp on their own or make a carb monster and mix them with my kimchi fried rice? Don't mind if I do both. 

This meal was an embarrassment of gluttony. Despite being members of the clean plate club, we couldn't finish... our food. The soju, we kept flowing and put a hurt on it. Again, #priorities.

*We've come a long way from burgers and shakes.
**She kicked my butt.
author: Johnny T.

description:
Drool over the menu, curse everyone and their mothers while you wait forever for the food, then forgive them all over again when the food arrives.

On a Saturday night here once my partner and I waited an hour after ordering before the food arrived.  It was completely unacceptable.  At the same time, the soup they make here is my lifeblood.  I'm so conflicted about this restaurant.  I don't know how authentically Korean this food is, but I want to try everything on the menu.


---- Small Plates ----

Steamed Egg Custard: 3 stars
The egg was a bit coarse.  I prefer a silkier texture, like Chinese egg tofu.


---- Soup ----

Beef Brisket Soup: 5 stars
It's like everything you could possibly want in a soup.

Dumpling Soup:  4 stars
Pork dumplings and tender beef brisket in an eggy soup.


---- BBQ Hot Plates ----

Pork Belly: 3 stars
On the dry side.

Spicy Pork BBQ: 4 stars
Delicious tender BBQ pork, but you'll be disappointed if you wanted something spicy.


---- Stir-Fried ----

Combination Pancake: 4.5 stars
Kimchi and seafood.  So yummy.

Spicy Pork Clear Noodles: 4.5 stars
I love chapchae. Not too spicy for me, which means it's pretty darn mild.
author: Letitia L.

description:
New Korean on the block. Clearly they are still working some kinks out. With 707 and Cocobang around the corner, they will have to step up their game to win in the competition. Place is big, a little smaller than 707, but twice the size of Coco. Pretty big menu with happy hour drinks on tap. Like the others, K-pop music videos are projected onto the wall for your dining entertainment.

Ordered:
Spicy pork noodle: Good flavoring, nothing spectacular.

Soon do bu: The initial soup was burnt. It came boiling and the bowl was popping from the tray. The taste was over powered by the charred burnt taste...I wasn't about to spend $13 on uneaten soup. We had to send it back and the waitress was very apologetic. Our burnt soup was replaced by a new one and she even gave us a new egg to drop in. Unfortunately, for me the flavor was a bit lacking. My favorite tofu soup in the area still has to be from 707. 

They have a pretty reasonable lunch menu that I have yet to try. The place is promising, hopefully with time things will improve!
author: Michelle C.

description:
I had an urge for some Korean food, so I went to Cocobang. It was crowded and I had to wait. So I walked around the block and discovered ZZAN. Got seated immediately. 
Ordered some fried chicken, which was very good. We also had the beef bulgogi and spicy ramen, awesome!!! I was really glad I came. The service was fast and friendly. There were two guys that was really fun and efficient. Yogurt soju was the bomb.
I was very hungry and I was not disappointed.
author: Jeff L.

description: First time here. Wouldn't come back. Very low lighting inside the building. Service was friendly and prompt. But the food was not the freshest the kimchi fried rice had good flavor but was a little underwhelming. And the spicy pork BBQ was almost all spice with not much other flavors.
author: James T.

description: Awesome spot! Good vibe, and they got Kpop music videos on the wall playing. The music does play a little loud, though. Favorite dish has to be the creamy rice cake. Also got the skewers, which were bomb, but their wings were not as good as their other dishes. It felt like they used bad oil when cooking them.
author: Do P.

description: The soft tofu stew here tastes great. The waitress gave us seafood pancake after we waited quite some time for our food to be served. Good service
author: Annie C.

description: A new Korean eatery is in the neighborhood yay!  I stopped by during the week for their lunch specials.  I loved the salad and banchan included.  The meat portion (I had the BBQ chicken) was a bit small, but for the lunch special price, I can't complain.  Service was friendly, prompt and checked on me as needed.
author: Maile N.

description: This place is across the street from the hotel we stayed at and after a full day we needed some late night eats. Zzan did not disappoint! The kimchi fried rice was delicious, beer was cold and they had hip hop music videos projected on the wall. Perfect little spot
author: Lizzy D.

description: Came here on a Thursday night and most of the place was not busy at all so it was nice. The food itself is ok. We got the budaejjigae, wings, pancake and some other items i forget. Place is kind of small so only long narrow tables. We had a group of 8 and sharing food was a bit of a pickle when it came to passing things back and forth. A round table would have definitely made a better experience but that would never fit in there. Overall it was a pleasant experience but I wouldn't say it was amazing. The staff was just two guys for the night and service a tad slow but bearable. I wish they had the Korean buttons you can press for service.
author: edward k.

description:
Another legit Korean hang out venue in my area! *Raise my soju cup in celebration*
Zzan's Korean fried chicken was soooo delicious! Before I knew it, I almost single handedly downed the whole thing. The staffs are friendly and attentive. I'll be back for more soju bombs and delicious goodness!
author: Jenny T.

description:
Food is good but service is really bad! 
No one come to take my order. When I tried to tell them I'm ready. They told me wait and just talked with their co worker. Ignore the customer.
author: Aunggie N.

description: Came here with a colleague for dinner. We opted for the pitcher, which is more like a 64oz plastic bottle of beer. Ordered some food. The spicy chicken dish with cheese was awesome, my friends beef bolgogi was decent. I will be back for that tasty chicken! so hot!
author: Jonah K.

description:
Never been here but delivered twice to my high rise. I love the authenticity of Korean flavors and no Asian Fusion crap. I'm Korean American for 42 years and would really appreciate if the restaurant would add the Korean name of the dishes because I am not familiar with the exact ingredients....my mom just cooked and we never asked. Please add a little Korean comment for Korean American people who want the words Jaja myun or Kimchi Jija...Galbi, bulgogi, soon dubu jijee. Dopokee....please. That would be the bomb!!! Korean and American ordering. Thai , Vietnamese, Indian restaurants don't make up goofy names for their dishes.  Only Korean, Chinese and Japanese restaurants make up goofy dishes.

Dragon Roll
Seafood Pancake
Tempura Rolls
Kung Pow
General's  Chicken
Laughing Duck

What the crimmeny happened to Asian cuisine and the unique names. Let's all speak in Spanish too at Asian Restaurants because it's cool to be bi-lingual. Ok. My post is long enough. Pahhha hahaha!
author: Kathy S.

description:
I went here with my family for Christmas Eve dinner. We were seated immediately. We ordered bulgogi beef, spicy pork, potstickers, calamari, and tofu soup. The service was quick and the food was delicious! The price was also very reasonable for the generous amount of food.

This is a great dining spot for people in their 20s. Rap music was played accompanied by music videos projected on the wall. The lighting was dim and it created a really hip ambiance.

I will definitely come back next time I visit San Francisco. Would definitely recommend to friends and family.
author: Drake S.

description: Had the Bibimbap.  Arrived in a beautiful bento box! Everything in the box complimented the amazingly marinated beef short ribs!  Warm friendly quick service! Yummy!!!
author: Koichi D.

description: Dear Zzan manager, I expect a reply. 0 STARS! Just paid $11 for what was supposed to be Steamed Sausage with vegetables with a sauce. THIS is what I got. One sausage link that has been sliced in to pieces with a sprinkling of dry, shredded lettuce?! It's cold. It's rubbery, yet dry. Has NO flavor. And does not even resemble the picture that is posted in their pictures of this item. Not in any way. Taste is disgusting, and this is deceptive and such a ripoff.
author: Amanda P.

description:
Inconsistent. First time I came here back when they had just opened, the tofu soup was very flavorful and had a nice spiciness to it - in my opinion, it was one of the best I'd had in the city. Came here last night and it was SUPER watered down. No spiciness, no salt, and just very little flavor. I added kimchi to the soup to give it some excitement. 

I think they're understaffed/experiencing growing pains. The place is gaining traction so they need to staff up (service was very slow even though the wait staff was working very hard) and maintain consistency in food quality despite high customer volume. 

Hope they can get back to where they were when they first opened.
author: Jeffrey Z.

description:
I swear, ZZan has the best Korean food in the area. I lived in Korea for a few years and this place does it right and for fair prices. 

Must haves:

Fried chicken. The soy ginger sauce is sweet. The spicy sauce is the bomb. For $14 you get a giant pile of wings and drummies. Fried crispy.

Clear noodles with beef (jop chae). Best dish on the menu. Includes soy-based bulgogi, onions and mushrooms. To die for.

Beef brisket soup (yuk kae jung). Mind blowing soup. Very spicy but a large bowl of soup that will cure any ailment or hangover.

Pancakes (pah jun). I really enjoy the seafood one with chunks of octopus. The kimchi one is also delicious.

Meh.

Spicy pork. Served sizzling and with rice. The flavor just isn't there and it's not really spicy. The price is high at $16.

Go here. Eat the food. Listen to some K pop.
author: Sarah S.

description:
I'm from LA which I guess means that my Korean food standards are fairly high. 

I got the tofu with dumplings, which tasted a little off. I can't put my finger to it but it didn't taste like "home" if I could call it that. 

My friend got the bibimbap and enjoyed it, and I've heard that the bulgogi is great so I may just have ordered the wrong dish.

I guess I'll have to come back to find out!
author: Anna M.

description: The best Korean food that I have ever had.  Shame I had to fly out to San Francisco to have it.  Anytime you want to open up a place in the Lou, that would be great.   Thanks for the wonderful food, great service and beautiful atmosphere!!!
author: Mark W.

description:
My friends and I came in on a Friday evening and I was surprised to see the restaurant was not very full. The service was great and our food came out very quickly after we ordered. Zzan has a late night vibe, as the restaurant is narrow and dark, and there are large TVs playing various Korean music videos on the wall.

I got the dolsot bulgogi bibimbap and my friend got the tofu soup with dumplings. My friend thought her soup was okay but I thought the bulgogi bibimbap was really good because the meat was so flavorful and well marinated. (Some places cheat and make the bulgogi in the bibimbap drier with less flavor.) This place was great!
author: Rica Z.

description:
Ahhhhh Zzan!!! I have not stepped inside this restaurant yet, to be truthful, but I had deliveries from Postmates , and I have to say I love the food here. 
The best one ,of course, is the kalbi. It was excellent each and every time I ordered it. Finger licking excellent, if you asked me. The chicken was good too, so tender and juicy. The pork belly was another favorite. And the bibimbap was flavorful,with all the vegetables, I only wish they had cooked it longer in the stone pot, because I love the crusty rice. 
The one star off was for the inconsistency on the amount of rice given. The very last delivery, there was not enough rice. Maybe I should put a note next time when ordering.
author: lovetoeat a.

description: This is my new favorite resturant.  The creamy rice cake noodles are so good. The service is on point and the prices are reasonable. I would recommend this spot to everyone, whether it be for a small meal and a beer or a nice family dinner.
author: C H.

description: Looking for some Pho close to the hotel I called no joy and tried this place instead. Great beef brisket soup! Very hearty and flavorful.  The place has K Pop videos on the wall. Has a dark vibe like Pulp Fiction. The menu choices are vast so they have something for everyone.
author: Scott W.

description:
Solid. Cocobang and 707 needed some healthy competition, and here it is -- "ZZAN!"

This isn't really a place to take your entire family and expect 900 side dishes to be refilled 7x during your stay. Come, drink, snack, enjoy the buzz. This family-run joint serves up recognizable Korean fare at (sad to say) average SF prices. 

Dishes had on first visit:
- Army stew (budaejjigae): looks are deceiving. Fed 3 of us until we were stuffed. At $25.95, it's cheaper than Toyose and Playground, I believe.
- Chicken karaage with spicy sauce (#69) $10.95. Yummy! Reminded me of a Korean version of General Tso.

They have a few beers on tap, soju cocktails, and tons of other dishes I need to try on my next visit. Banchan selection could be better (unripe kimchi gives me sadface), and averages around ~3 dishes.

Fast, friendly service and loud KPOP music videos being projected onto the wall. I'll be baaaack.

The 1 star reviews are obviously written by Zzan's competitors in this hood (no reviews or friends and/or highly rating 707? OOoooook). That's really low and lame.

--Edited--

Additional dishes tried:
- Creamy ddukbokki ("Stir Fried Creamy Rice Cake" on the menu) $12.95. YUMMY! I wasn't expecting to like this but was like ddukbokki and carbonara (bacon included) and it was both spicy and the right amount of salty. The ddukbokki (rice cakes) were cooked over more than the standard chewiness, but I actually liked it and the consistency reminded me of gnocchi.
- Yukgaejang ("Beef Brisket Soup" on the menu) $12.95. It had a good, mildly spicy flavor and the beef was really tender. But it was lacking a few classic ingredients so it was only OK.
- Pan Fried Dumping $7.95. Very tasty and beefy. The skins were not dry on the outside like gyoza in some places I've had before. Decent starter to whet your table's appetites. (Full disclosure, though - I am obsessed with dumplings.)
author: Stephanie M.

description:
Zaan is a pretty cool place that has a video project of music videos. The inside is kind of dark and lit up with florescent lights. There's enough tables inside to fit around 20 people. It's good for large parties also since the tables can be pushed together for larger parties.

== Food ==

The bulgogi was pretty good. The beef was a bit too chewy though. The rice I got was overcooked. The side dishes were pretty standard. Kimchi, pickled something, fish cakes, some greens, and some white clear stuff.

== Service ==

Food came out pretty fast and the service is pretty good.

== Overall ==

Pretty good place to grab some Korean food. The atmosphere is the biggest selling point of this place.
author: Steven B.

description:
They skimp on the meat in the dishes. 
We got the kim chi friend rice with spam and you can barely taste or find any spam. This was also the same case for the beef tofu soup. 

The chicken wings were also saucy, but the chicken itself was a lot more difficult to pull off the bones. In addition, the meat was dry. 

Gave it a try, but Cocobang or 707 would be better options.
author: Suzie B.

description: The waiter here sucks and he's very rude. He was trying to kick us out because they were "busy".... even though they had plenty of empty tables. Left a bad tip and he threw it.
author: Jaewon K.

description:
This is for Zzan's delivery business which is the most unorganized delivery service I've encountered so far in SF. I put in my order of only THREE items at around 840 pm on a Thursday night and the estimated time of arrival was supposed to be 945. Fine, an hour... That was okay with me since most businesses always say that but usually do come faster. Around 940, I messaged eat24 who assured me the order was on the way. At 10, the order was still not here so I called the restaurant who informed me that the order was still there and the person from eat24 didn't pick it up yet. I was livid at this point and immediately messaged eat24 who was also confused about why the order was so delayed. 

At around 10:05, the order did come but boy, did it come with serious errors. First of all, I ordered the seafood soontofu which was an extra dollar but I got the veggie one. Kimchi fried rice came with pork when I specifically stated beef. That's 2 of the 3 dishes which I also had to pay extra for! The food was also mediocre and everything was either too saucy or too salty. 

The girl who I called at Zzan earlier called me back and said it was their mistake. They messed up my order which is why they thought it wasn't delivered - she offered to send the dish again but I declined. Save yourself the trouble and don't bother ordering from this place.
author: Sherina Y.

description: Terrible service on delivery. Either pork in my vegetarian food or smashed up food from inappropriate packaging. ALWAYS leaking everywhere. And NEVER wants to be responsible blames it on delivery service and they are wasting my time in the middle of the night after ruining my dinner refusing to give a refund. Food half the time tastes terrible this place is off my list forever
author: Hyun B.

description:
Came here because 707 was closed on Thanksgiving Eve. Zzan is really small and the decor is kind of confused but it doesn't take away from the typical K-bar experience. There were only two waitresses and they were super busy and backed up the whole night. When I went to the restroom, I also peeked into the kitchen and saw that there were only two cooks as well. Hats off to them for handling that large dinner/late-night munchies rush! At one point, they even ran out of dishes and had to serve on paper places. 

Onto the food -- between my friend and me, we got an order of the chicken wings with soy glaze, kimchi fried rice with spicy pork, soondubu jiggae with beef (mild), and a pitcher of mango soju.

Their chicken wings are really big and plump but the soy glaze costed extra and wasn't particularly tasty. Even though I ordered the soondubu jiggae mild, it came pretty spicy. I'm wondering if they forgot that I ordered it mild or if their mild is more spicy than what I'm used to with other places. Their kimchi fried rice was standard. Mango soju was very icy and towards the end, super thick and syrupy. I might stick with Yogurt soju next time. 

By the way, their banchan is ON POINT!! Kimchi and radish kimchi were some of the tastiest I've had in a long, long time!
author: Maggi K.

description:
Zzan has been an itch I've had for a few months.  I'd come to San Francisco last year for a wedding and the weekend was packed so I made a mental note to come back.
